required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Response of the Muscles of the Back and Thigh in Road and Mountain Bikers.
clinical_study.official_title: Response of the Muscles of the Back and Thigh in Road and Mountain Bikers After 3 Hours Cycling Task.

brief_summary.textblock:
The two most important problems of the musculoskeletal system in cyclists are low back pain (60%) and knee pain (33%). There is no clear hypothesis about the development of low back pain in cyclists, but several authors agree that it may be due to the maintenance of a maintained posture, with the lumbar spine in inversion and the characteristics associated with this sport (long duration, static posture, high intensities), so it is recommended a preparation of the musculature (strength-endurance work) and exercises to improve the postural scheme in the cyclist.
The project proposes to analyze the acute effect of a long-lasting bicycle trip (3 hours) on the muscles involved in low back and knee pain, see, lumbar paravertebral, quadriceps and hamstrings, by means of tensiomyography (TMG).

detailed_description.textblock:
The participation in the study requires only 2 assistances to the data takings that will be developed in the training laboratory of the Faculty of Sciences of Physical Activity and Sport of the European University. Said sessions will begin with an initial assessment, which will be carried out: an anthropometric assessment (height and weight), evaluation of pain tests with the EVA scale, the threshold of pain pressure and a questionnaire, muscle assessment with the tension monitor, a non-invasive tool that allows us to evaluate the contractile properties of superficial muscles through an isometric contraction induced by electrostimulation, and the assessment of mobility of the lumbar spine.
Once the initial assessment is completed, the participants will perform a brief 8-minute cycle ergometer warm-up, repeat the initial assessments once again and make a bicycle trip through a previously programmed route lasting approximately 3 hours. Upon return, the participants will return to all previous assessments.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: There are two groups and each participant participate in both groups.
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: It is a variable derived from the tensiomiographic assessment. Measured in millimeters (mm). Higher values represent a lower muscle stiffness, and lower values represent higher muscle stiffness of the examined muscle.

secondary_outcome.description: This variable records the pain perceived by using the Visual analogue scale (VAS), a numerical scale from 0 to 10. Higher values represent a worse outcome, and lower values represent better outcome.
It is a continuous quantitative variable expressed in kg / cm2. It allows to measure the intensity of pain. It is taken from the average of 3 repetitions on the same point.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of Extensibility of hamstring muscles
secondary_outcome.description: It is a continuous quantitative variable expressed in degrees (º). It is obtained with the AKE test (active knee extension).
It is a variable derived from the tensiomiographic assessment. Of continuous quantitative type and measured in milliseconds (ms).
It is a variable derived from the tensiomiographic assessment. Of continuous quantitative type and measured in milliseconds (ms).

arm_group.description: They will be examined before and after 3 hour road cycling task.
They will be examined before and after 3 hour mountain-biking task.

intervention.description: All the participants will complete a 3 hours cycling task at the 60-80% of their maximal estimated hearth rate.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Be a man
- Aged between 18 and 55 years.
- Minimum experience in the practice of cycling over 3 years
- Accumulate at least 200 hours of training each year.
- Not having received specific treatment in the musculature evaluated in the last 4 weeks, or being subjected to any treatment at present.
- No pathology diagnosed in the anatomical regions interested in the study (lumbar, thigh, hip or knee).
- Sign the informed consent.
Exclusion criteria
- Have had strenuous exercise in the previous 48 hours
- Having taken energy drinks in the last 48 hours
- Have ingested alcohol or caffeine in the 3 hours prior to taking data.
